snippet: An exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art offers visitors a chance to gain a new perspective on Andrew Wyeth, who died in 2009.
abstract: Sylviane Gold reviews paintings by Andrew Wyeth at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford (Metropolitan/Connecticut). Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Blown against a gray granite rock face by a winter's worth of wind, the brown-and-beige mound of tangled leaves, twigs and dry pine needles seemed to be lying by the road waiting for a painter to happen by. Especially a painter enamored of muted color, desiccated texture and minute detail. I'm sure I've passed innumerable such heaps of roadside debris without ever actually seeing them. But this time, I was headed home from Hartford after a visit to the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art and its show of some two dozen works by Andrew Wyeth. Whether you disdain him as an anachronistic sentimentalist, revere him as a scrupulous chronicler of rock-ribbed Americana, or accept his own assessment that he was an abstractionist in realist clothing, ''Andrew Wyeth: Looking Beyond'' can alter your perspective.
